results.title: Shrek storyboard pitch
results.brief_description: Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man in one of the most memorable scenes in Shrek (2001), but before the bit appeared in the movie, storyboard artist Conrad Vernon performed it as a ‘pitch’ to the filmmaking team.
results.description:
Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man in one of the most memorable scenes in Shrek (2001), but before the bit appeared in the movie, storyboard artist Conrad Vernon performed it as a ‘pitch’ to the filmmaking team.

Animated films aren’t always scripted from start to finish, so teams of artists collaborate on developing scenes and stories they then perform to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film.

Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers and storytellers as well as visual artists. Vernon was definitely a triple threat, and his performance as Gingy in the pitch was so impressive that he voiced the fan-favourite character in the movie.
description_for_label:
Lord Farquaad ruthlessly (and hilariously) interrogates Gingerbread Man in one of the most memorable scenes in Shrek (2001), but before the bit appeared in the movie, storyboard artist Conrad Vernon performed it as a ‘pitch’ to the filmmaking team.

Animated films aren’t always scripted from start to finish, so teams of artists collaborate on developing scenes and stories they then perform to show how the rhythm and visuals will fit in the completed film.

Because of the close relationship between story, pacing and drawing, storyboard artists need to be performers and storytellers as well as visual artists. Vernon was definitely a triple threat, and his performance as Gingy in the pitch was so impressive that he voiced the fan-favourite character in the movie.

results.title: Shrek [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Vicky Jenson, Andrew Adamson, Jeffrey Katzenberg, John H. Williams, Aron Warner and NBCUniversal
results.brief_description: Once upon a time in a land far, far away, and so begins this animated fantasy. Set in a fantastical kingdom inhabited by fairy tale creatures, the story finds the enchanted princess, Fiona (Cameron Diaz) locked away in a tower guarded by a dragon; a scheming Lord Farquaard (John Lithgow) who wants to marry the princess so he can become King; an unlikely hero, the lovable ogre Shrek (Mike Myers) and his sidekick, Donkey (Eddie Murphy), who are sent by Farquaard to rescue the princess and bring her back to be his bride. Children will enjoy the tale for what it is - a lively romp, while adults will enjoy the many intertextual references to numerous other fairy tales.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vicky Jenson, Andrew Adamson, Jeffrey Katzenberg, John H. Williams, Aron Warner and NBCUniversal

results.title: Shred of evidence
results.brief_description: This program looks at the work done by the Forensic Science Laboratory in London which was founded in 1935. It’s aim is to outwit the criminal and provide evidence for the court. Some scenes may be upsetting to some people.
results.description: This program looks at the work done by the Forensic Science Laboratory in London which was founded in 1935. It’s aim is to outwit the criminal and provide evidence for the court. Some scenes may be upsetting to some people.

results.title: Showtime [b&w]
results.creator_credit: Anne Bourke and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: A film of the Royal Melbourne show as seen through the eyes of a family group. Grandfather, a retired farmer, takes his daughter and her two teenage children to the show. To people like breeders of livestock, farmers and agricultural equipment salesmen, the show is an important yearly event, but for the family there is something to interest each member. Cooking demonstrations, displays of horsermanship, and the extensive pavilions showing domestic pets as well as farm animals all have their appeal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anne Bourke and State Film Centre of Victoria

results.title: Showtime
results.creator_credit: Anne Bourke and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description:
A film of the Royal Melbourne Show as seen through the eyes of a family group. Grandfather, a retired farmer, takes his daughter and her two teenage children to the show. To people like breeders of livestock, farmers and agricultural equipment salesmen, the show is an important yearly event, but for the family there is something to interest each member. Cooking demonstrations, displays of horsemanship, and the extensive pavilions showing domestic pets as well as farm animals all have their appeal.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:14:00 animated graphics title ‘Showtime’, ‘produced by State Film Centre Victoria Westrex Sound’
00:00:30:00 a 1950s model crane truck
00:00:45:00 a 1950s model electricians van with lettering for ‘RHC Sound System’
00:00:57:00 scenes of preparing for the Show - cleaning, painting tyres and signs, brushing cattle
00:01:26:00 first look at animals on show in the main arena
00:02:16:00 draft horses
00:02:26:00 goats
00:02:35:00 and showing off the fleece on a large ram and holding a large rooster up to the camera
00:02:50:00 the Berkshire pigs at the Show
00:03:02:00 a ‘red rattler’ style Show Special train pulls into the platform and people disembark, including the narrator and his family who quickly start looking at exhibits at the Show
00:03:53:00 first showbag pavilion
00:04:05:00 signs for popular soft drink at the time. Tarax
00:04:30:00 the Guernsey cattle pavilion
00:05:06:00 bundles of wheat and Government information about wheat on display
00:05:29:00 baby hen chicks
00:05:55:00 large flock of sheep
00:06:05:00 Centenary Hall at the Melbourne Showgrounds followed by exhibitions of shearing sheep with hand shears and then with electric shears
00:06:35:00 a fashion parade at the Show followed by doll making and hand knits craft exhibition
00:07:27:00 looking at exhibitions of food preservation, tiered wedding cakes, and cooking class on laminations
00:07:45:00 whitegoods exhibition beginning with a well stocked drinks cabinet with built in fridge and semi-automatic washing machine in action
00:07:59:00 an exhibition set up as a butchers shop shows sausage making
00:08:15:00 the wood-chopping exhibition and competition at the Show followed by exhibition of different types of chainsaws
00:09:00:00 the diary pavilion
00:09:17:00 inspecting the brand new, shining Massey-Ferguson tractors tried out by very keen young man of the family
00:09:44:00 new motor cars on show including a promotion for the new Ford Zephyr
00:09:55:00 carnival rides including the ‘Noddy Car Ride’ (character featured in Enid Blyton books)
00:10:30:00 aerial view of the Showgrounds
00:10:46:00 sideshow tents
00:11:47:00 fairy floss tent
00:11:55:00 cut flowers pavilion
00:12:16:00 dog show
00:13:30:00 the Australian Mint exhibition followed by several show bag stalls
00:14:15:00 crowds at the main arena followed by horse jumping, harness racing and other competitions, including what might be sheaf sack tossing
00:15:09:00 the Grand Parade in the main arena at the Show which includes many of the exhibitors, winners and placegetters
00:17:07:00 fireworks and title ‘The End’

results.title: Shows Promise: Should Go Far (Exceptional Children)
results.brief_description: A study of four exceptional children in one family, each excelling in at least one area of learning. Examines their upbringing and the key role played by their mother who has been influenced by Montessori.
results.description: A study of four exceptional children in one family, each excelling in at least one area of learning. Examines their upbringing and the key role played by their mother who has been influenced by Montessori.

results.title: Shows promise - should go far (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Tuchner, Michael Deakin and Yorkshire Harlech Television
results.brief_description: A study of four exceptional children in one family. Each child excels in at least one area of learning, eg., mathematics, music, painting. The film looks at the children’s upbringing and its influence on their development. Their mother explains her situation and philosophy underlying her upbringing of the children.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Tuchner, Michael Deakin and Yorkshire Harlech Television

results.title: Shown by request
results.creator_credit: Colin Dean, Alexander Shaw and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: Story of 16 mm film use and distribution in Great Britain. Films being used in village hall, in the country, during a factory lunch hour; how the film library works, the procedures in handling a new film and the method of handling requests through all steps until the film has been returned, repaired and put back in the vault.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Dean, Alexander Shaw and Crown Film Unit

results.title: Showgirls
results.creator_credit: Paul Verhoeven, Alan Marshall, Charles Evans, United Artists Corporation and Chargetex 6 S A
results.brief_description: Topping worst film of the year lists and castigated by critics as “distasteful”, “sleazy” and “high gloss trash”, Paul Verhoeven’s “Showgirls” is unashamedly trashy, completely unpretentious, genre fun. That it provoked such knee-jerk reactions only shows just how ahead of the game it is. With nothing to lose, the young, feisty Nomi Malone hitches a ride to Las Vegas to become a dancer. She starts off working at The Cheetah, a sleazy striptease, lap-dancing joint, before catching the attention of Cristal Connors, star of Las Vegas’ most upscale dancehall-casino. The sensuous, quasi-dominatrix, Cristal, is attracted to Nomi and impressed by her dancing skills. Eventually, Nomi is accepted into the exclusive dance show and is able to strut her stuff. We get to witness the level of bitchiness behind the stage in the dressing room where the fiercest is between Nomi and Cristal. This bitchiness, which borders on lust and attraction, intensifies when Nomi starts dating Zack Carey, Cristal’s current lover and the show’s Executive Director, who consequently promotes Nomi to the position of Cristal’s understudy. A la “All About Eve”, Nomi eventually gets her chance as the show’s lead and becomes the toast of town. It’s at the top, however, that Nomi witnesses firsthand the corruption and evil that runs riot in Las Vegas. Written by one of Hollywood’s highest paid screenwriters and regular Verhoeven collaborator, Joe Eszterhas, “Showgirls” is filled with lowly, tawdry behaviour, cliches and plot points: bitchiness, infantile power games, old-fashioned representations of gender and sex, naked ambition, sexist machismo, and even an odd value system which sees Nomi making claims to artistry and objecting to charges of being a whore whilst at the same time climbing the ladder via sleeping with her boss and giving audiences all the body they can muster. But like all good B-grade, exploitation cinema, Verhoeven indulges in genre cinema and lowly attitudes of sex and gender in a highly energised, dazzling mode in order to give them a new spin. Ultimately, “Showgirls” is an honest portrayal of the superficiality and tawdriness of Las Vegas, aka America. Stars Elizabeth Berkley, Kyle MacLachlan, Gina Gershon, Glenn Plummer.
